text:
They were all feeling super awkward.  
“Goodbye, Rodya. Until next time. I hate saying goodbye. Goodbye, Nastasya. Oops, said it again.”  
Pulcheria Alexandrovna wanted to say hi to Sonia too, but it didn’t happen, and she hurried out of the room.  
Avdotya Romanovna seemed to be waiting for her turn. When she followed her mom out, she gave Sonia a polite bow. Sonia, feeling nervous, quickly curtsied. She looked really uncomfortable, like Avdotya’s attention was too much for her.  
“Dounia, goodbye!” Raskolnikov called from the hallway. “Give me your hand.”  
“I did give it to you. Did you forget?” Dounia replied, turning to him with a mix of warmth and awkwardness.  
“Doesn’t matter, give it to me again.” He squeezed her fingers warmly.  
Dounia smiled, blushed, pulled her hand back, and left feeling pretty happy.  
“Now that’s great,” he said to Sonia, returning to her with a bright look. “Rest in peace to the dead; the living still have to live. That’s true, right?”  
Sonia was surprised by the sudden spark in his face. He stared at her for a moment, memories of his late father flashing through his mind…

**PAGE SUMMARY:** The characters experience a mix of embarrassment and emotional connection as they say their goodbyes, highlighting their complex relationships.
